Dear Mr. Mossburg:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.

Sincerely,

ALLEGATION:
Foster care workers are not conducting face-to-face visits with foster children at the
summer home.
INVESTIGATION:
Chief Administrator was advised of new complaint via email on July 29, 2022.
Complainant was interviewed via telephone on August 5, 2022. She stated the
family have been staying at their summer residence since June 10, 2022.
Complainant stated she was concerned the agency foster care workers were not
completing home visits to the summer residence and specifically to ensure Youth
C’s safety plan that are part of the foster care case is being followed. Complainant
stated she conducted a home visit to the summer residence on July 22, 2022. She
stated the family never mentioned any concerns regarding COVID.
Foster parent (FP) was interviewed via telephone on August 16, 2022. FP stated
there was a face-to-face visit by an agency foster care worker in her summer
2

residence but some of the visits were done virtually. FP stated there was exposure
to COVID in her household in June and July. She stated there is a youth in her home
with a compromised immune system, so she is extremely cautious when allowing
visitors.
Foster Care Worker 1 (FCW1) was interviewed via telephone on August 23, 2022.
FCW1 stated she was first assigned to Youth A and Youth B’s case in May and was
informed at the time of assignment the family requested virtual visits due to concerns
of COVID. FCW1 stated she continued to conduct virtual visits as the family
requested and as she was instructed to do so by the previous foster care worker as
well as her supervisor. FCW1 was informed the family preferred virtual visits due to
having an immunocompromised child in the home and would advise when the foster
parents felt comfortable allowing people in their house. FCW1 stated she has not
been inside the foster parent’s main house or their summer house as she is new to
the case.
Foster Care Worker 2 (FCW2) was interviewed via telephone on August 23, 2022.
FCW2 stated she is the assigned foster care worker for Youth C. FCW2 stated
Youth C is currently in treatment so there is more contact with her by a behavioral
specialist. She stated the foster parents requested virtual visits due to concerns
regarding COVID because they have a child in the home with significant health
issues. The foster parents will ask FCW2 if she is displaying any COVID related
symptoms or if anyone in the household is she will request a virtual visit.
Foster Care Supervisor 1 (FC Supervisor 1) was interviewed via telephone on
August 29, 2022. FC Supervisor 1 stated she has been assigned to the case since
February 2022. She stated the foster family has requested virtual visits for several
months due to concern regarding COVID-19. FC Supervisor 1 stated the foster
parents have a child in the home with a compromised immune system due to a
significant health condition. She stated her staff have been conducting virtual visits
with Youth A and Youth B due to the request by foster parents. FC Supervisor 1
stated FCW1 inquires every month if anyone in the household is experiencing
symptoms even if the visits are virtual. A home visit was conducted in the vacation
home of foster family in July 2022 due to concerns that were recently brought up.
Foster Care Supervisor 2 (FC Supervisor 2) was interviewed via telephone on
August 30, 2022. FC Supervisor 2 stated she is the supervisor assigned to Youth
C’s case. She stated the foster parents have expressed concern regarding COVID-
19 due to having a few children in the home with a compromised immune system but
the assigned foster care worker conducts monthly visits in the foster placement,
including their vacation home. FC Supervisor 2 stated typically the assigned worker
she supervised will see the child in the main home in June and August and will travel
to the vacation home for the July visit.

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time
(b) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster
child and foster parent in the foster parent’s home at least
once every month.
4

ANALYSIS: The agency is found in noncompliance as the assigned
caseworkers did not complete all required monthly face-to-face
visits with foster children in the foster home.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
I recommend upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan no change be
made to the license status of this child placing agency.
